abstract.p: Detroit Tigers defeat Cleveland Indians, 13-2; other American League results noted (M)

block.p: Juan Gonzalez, who rejected a one-year contract extension to collapse a proposed three-for-one trade to the Yankees yesterday, helped the Detroit Tigers to a 13-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians last night at Jacobs Field.

The two-time most valuable player went 3 for 4 with a run-scoring triple, scored twice and walked as the Tigers went 7-6 against the Indians this year, winning the season series for the first time since 1993.

Juan Gonzalez, who rejected a one-year contract extension to collapse a proposed three-for-one trade to the Yankees yesterday, helped the Detroit Tigers to a 13-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians last night at Jacobs Field.

The two-time most valuable player went 3 for 4 with a run-scoring triple, scored twice and walked as the Tigers went 7-6 against the Indians this year, winning the season series for the first time since 1993.
Instead of playing for the Yankees, Gonzalez will now face them tonight at home.
Brian Moehler (5-4) pitched six and two-thirds innings for his fourth victory in six decisions. The right-hander gave up seven hits, walked three and struck out three.
Tony Clark went 3 for 5 with a homer and three runs batted in and Juan Encarnacion had four hits, including a two-run double, in Detroit's four-run sixth inning.
Bobby Higginson threw out two runners for the Tigers. He leads the American League with eight outfield assists.

In dropping three of five to the last-place Tigers, the Indians fell eight and a half games behind first-place Chicago in the A.L. Central. Cleveland is 13-17 in a division it has dominated since 1995.
TWINS 10, ANGELS 6: Matt Lawton, Ron Coomer and Jay Canizaro each homered and had two R.B.I. for visiting Minnesota.

Brad Radke (5-9), who won for only the second time in seven starts, allowed two runs and six hits in six innings. He struck out two and walked two as the Twins salvaged a split of the four-game series.

Jarrod Washburn (3-2), who gave up only three earned runs in 22 innings in his previous three outings, allowed eight runs and eight hits in three and a third innings -- his shortest outing in 30 major league starts.
One of the runs off the left-hander was unearned because of a throwing error by Scott Spiezio, who started his third straight game at third base because of Troy Glaus's back spasms.
